articles.headline: Its Forecast Dim, Fed Vows to Keep Rates Near Zero
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s hope is that a showman’s gesture will spur investment and risk-taking.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s hope is that a showman’s gesture will spur investment and risk-taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve made a rare promise on Tuesday to hold short-term interest rates near zero through at least the middle of 2013, in a sign that it has all but written off the chances of an expansion strong enough to drive up wages and prices.

articles.headline: Central Bank Props Up Spain and Italy, for Now
articles.snippet: After succeeding in pushing down the interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt, the European Central Bank still needs to convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand turmoil.
articles.abstract: After succeeding in pushing down the interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt, the European Central Bank still needs to convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank has succeeded at least temporarily in pushing down the effective interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt. But analysts say the bank must still convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand what could be a long struggle against market turmoil.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: On Its Own, Europe Backs Web Privacy Fights
articles.snippet: Spain is the latest country to champion a cause for Internet privacy by ordering Google to stop indexing certain information about its citizens.
articles.abstract: Spain is the latest country to champion a cause for Internet privacy by ordering Google to stop indexing certain information about its citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — All 90 people wanted information deleted from the Web.

articles.headline: Technology Investors Turn Wary on Ventures
articles.snippet: A “Madoff effect” and the smarting memory of the dot-com bust have combined to produce a newly cautious class of limited partners.
articles.abstract: A “Madoff effect” and the smarting memory of the dot-com bust have combined to produce a newly cautious class of limited partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — Even as Wall Street trembles, the market for investing in tech start-ups remains white-hot. Still, some investors are proceeding with extreme caution.

articles.headline: For Murdoch, a Board Meeting With Friendly Faces
articles.snippet: The closeness between News Corporation and its independent directors is an example of how chumminess in the boardroom can be a problem.
articles.abstract: The closeness between News Corporation and its independent directors is an example of how chumminess in the boardroom can be a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Rupert Murdoch sat down with his board on Tuesday for the first time since a phone hacking scandal overseas plunged his company into turmoil, he was surrounded by a lot of familiar, friendly faces.

articles.headline: Shares Suffer Again in a Blow to Market Confidence
articles.snippet: Investors appeared to pay closer attention to the Fed’s grim assessment of the prospects for the economic recovery and job growth.
articles.abstract: Investors appeared to pay closer attention to the Fed’s grim assessment of the prospects for the economic recovery and job growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market resumed its downward trajectory on Wednesday as American investors looked with renewed trepidation at the debt problems plaguing Europe and the United States’ sputtering economy.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Britain Debates Riots and Fears They Set a Pattern
articles.snippet: The police and political leaders worried about a pattern of interracial violence that could be set off by recent mayhem.
articles.abstract: The police and political leaders worried about a pattern of interracial violence that could be set off by recent mayhem.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Still reeling with shock and anger over the worst rioting in decades, Britain turned on Wednesday to a tough reckoning with the perpetrators, even as the police and political leaders worried about a potentially explosive new pattern of interracial violence that could be set off by the past four days of mayhem.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Support for Assad Government Shows Signs of Weakening
articles.snippet: As Syria, led by President Bashar al-Assad, continues its relentless assault on the uprising, its isolation is increasing as cracks form in the leadership.
articles.abstract: As Syria, led by President Bashar al-Assad, continues its relentless assault on the uprising, its isolation is increasing as cracks form in the leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syria continues its most relentless assault yet on a five-month uprising, killing more than a dozen protesters Wednesday, cracks have begun to emerge in a tight-knit leadership that has until now managed to rally its base of support and maintain a unified front, officials, dissidents and analysts say.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and Steven Lee Myers
